<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>Your Connection, Their Cash: Threat Actors Misuse SDKs to Sell Your Bandwidth</title>
	<meta name="description" content="A campaign leverages CVE-2024-36401 to stealthily monetize victims&#039; bandwidth where legitimate software development kits (SDKs) are deployed for passive income. Software development kits (SDKs) are deployed for passive income in a campaign leveraging CVE-2024-36401 to stealthily monetize victims&#039; bandwidth." />

<meta name="post_tags" content="CVE-2024-36401"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Your Connection, Their Cash: Threat Actors Misuse SDKs to Sell Your Bandwidth","name":"Your Connection, Their Cash: Threat Actors Misuse SDKs to Sell Your Bandwidth","description":"A campaign leverages CVE-2024-36401 to stealthily monetize victims' bandwidth where legitimate software development kits (SDKs) are deployed for passive income.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks\/","datePublished":"August 21, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nWe have detected a campaign aimed at gaining access to victims\u2019 machines and monetizing access to their bandwidth. It functions by exploiting the CVE-2024-36401 vulnerability in the GeoServer geospatial database. This Critical-severity remote code execution vulnerability has a CVSS score of 9.8. Criminals have used the vulnerability to deploy legitimate software development kits (SDKs) or modified apps to gain passive income via network sharing or residential proxies.\r\n\r\nThis method of generating passive income is particularly stealthy. It mimics a monetization strategy used by some legitimate app developers who choose SDKs instead of displaying traditional ads. This can be a well-intentioned choice that protects the user experience and improves app retention.\r\n\r\nThe applications we found in this malicious activity are nearly silent when operating. They consume minimal resources while monetizing victims' internet bandwidth, and without creating or distributing malware. This integration allows app developers to receive payments, while criminals profit from unused server resources, minimizing their risk of detection.\r\n\r\nSince March 2025, attackers have been probing GeoServer instances exposed to the internet. Cortex Xpanse reported 3,706 publicly accessible GeoServers in the first week of May 2025, indicating a potentially large attack surface for adversaries targeting CVE-2024-36401.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats described through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security\r\n \tCortex XDR\u00a0and XSIAM\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nVulnerabilities\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign Dissection\r\nWe have closely monitored a campaign that first emerged in early March 2025. The attackers have shifted infrastructure as well as tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) to maintain persistence.\r\n\r\nWe detected that attackers misused an SDK and an app during their campaign:\r\n\r\n \tThe SDK allowed developers to monetize other apps by collecting user data to earn passive income.\r\n \tThe app allowed users to earn passive income by sharing their internet connection.\r\n\r\nThe following timeline reveals how this threat has evolved.\r\nPhase 1: Initial Incursion (Early March 2025) With Misused SDKs\r\nThe campaign began with exploit attempts targeting CVE-2024-36401, then delivered the misused app and the misused SDK payloads.\r\n\r\n \tMarch 8, 2025: The campaign began with exploit attempts originating from the source IP address 108.251.152[.]209. The attacker used an exploit that targeted CVE-2024-36401.\r\n \tCustomized executable distribution: We observed these initial exploits fetching customized executables hosted at 37.187.74[.]75.\r\n \tTwo primary executables were distributed from this host:\r\n\r\n \tThe misused app: We detected variants of an application, including three that we have designated as a193, d193 and e193.\r\n \tThe misused SDK: We detected variants of an SDK, including five that we have designated as a593, c593, d593, s593 and z593.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 2: Shifting Tactics (Late March - Early April 2025) With Misused SDKs\r\nAttackers shifted tactics during this phase of the campaign.\r\n\r\n \tMarch 24, 2025: A few vendors on VirusTotal flagged the distribution IP address 37.187.74[.]75 as malicious. This shift indicates that the security community began recognizing malicious activity originating from that IP address. We believe this is a key factor that drove the threat actor to move their infrastructure to a different IP address.\r\n \tMarch 26, 2025: The attackers appeared to stop distributing new misused app samples. The focus seemingly shifted entirely to the misused SDK.\r\n \tApril 1, 2025: The threat actors switched their primary exploit delivery infrastructure to a new source IP address, 185.246.84[.]189. This was likely an attempt to evade blocklists and continue their operations unhindered.\r\n\r\nPhase 3: Infrastructure Expansion and Persistence (Mid-April 2025 - Ongoing)\r\nAttackers expanded their infrastructure during this phase of the campaign.\r\n\r\n \tApril 17, 2025: The attackers further expanded their backend infrastructure. They brought online a new customized executable distribution IP address, 64.226.112[.]52.\r\n \tThe original distribution IP address 37.187.74[.]75 remained live in mid-June.\r\n\r\nAs of this writing, exploit attempts continue from 185.246.84[.]189, and the customized executable distribution hosts remain online.\r\nCVE-2024-36401 Exploit Analysis\r\nThe core of this vulnerability lies in an attacker's ability to inject arbitrary code into JXPath query statements. JXPath is a library within the Apache Commons project that offers an XPath implementation.\r\n\r\nXPath is a widely adopted standard for querying and transforming XML documents. JXPath transparently extends the use of XPath expressions to various Java data structures beyond XML, including JavaBeans and multiple collections. From a security standpoint, this additional flexibility also introduces significant concerns.\r\n\r\nJXPath supports extension functionality, which an attacker can exploit if they gain control over the query statement, allowing them to execute arbitrary code. This poses a greater risk than typical query injection vulnerabilities.\r\n\r\nFor instance, attackers have used Standard Extension Functions to invoke methods like getRuntime().exec().\r\n\r\nFigure 1 shows an example of malicious code that leverages JXPath's ability to evaluate expressions, allowing an attacker to inject and execute arbitrary system commands via the #{cmd} placeholder. By referencing exec(java.lang.Runtime.getRuntime() within context.getValue, an attacker triggers Java's runtime execution mechanism, leading to remote code execution on the target system.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152586\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 1. Malicious code containing a JXPath referencing a Java execution function.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 2 reveals the payload from this attack. We redacted the key part of the payload in Figure 2. The redacted portion forces the victim to execute a system command to download a file from the attacker's host distribution IP addresses.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152597\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Payload from an exploit found in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAccording to the NVD:\r\nThis vulnerability has been confirmed to be exploitable through various Web Feature Service (WFS), Web Map Service (WMS), and Web Processing Service (WPS) requests, including GetFeature, GetPropertyValue, GetMap, GetFeatureInfo, GetLegendGraphic, and Execute requests.\r\nWhile analyzing an exploit used in this attack, we set up a GeoServer instance and used an in-the-wild exploit payload to analyze how the exploit works. We can see what is happening inside GeoServer by following its code flow.\r\n\r\nAfter we simulated sending an attack payload, our command was passed to the function GetPropertyValue. As shown at the bottom of Figure 3, the highlighted line takes the incoming request object and passes it to a run method. The command is carried by request.valueReference.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152608\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"917\"] Figure 3. Malicious payload entry point.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nStepping into this function reveals that the payload from Figure 2 was passed to the object propertyNameNoIndexes, shown from the exploit code in Figure 4. Later, this object invokes the Geotools method evaluate.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152619\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"985\"] Figure 4. The malicious payload is sent to an unsafe Geotools method.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nNote that we have entered the GeoTools codebase. The evaluate method retrieves the value of the Geotools attribute from the given object. Within this method, a PropertyAccessor object is used to read the property. Figure 5 shows that PropertyAccessor is a core interface that defines operations for reading and writing property values of an object. GeoTools will attempt to find an accessor based on the provided parameters.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152630\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"834\"] Figure 5. The malicious payload is sent to the object PropertyAccessor method findPropertyAccessors.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOnce an accessor has been successfully found, it will use the object's get method to retrieve the property value. Figure 6 shows that our payload has been passed into that method via the parameter attPath.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152641\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"845\"] Figure 6. A malicious payload is passed to attPath.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe object's get method invokes the JXPath library function iteratePointers. As shown in Figure 7, a payload is injected into the xpath variable, which is then passed to the context.iteratePointers method.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152652\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 7. JXPath function iteratePointers.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe ExtensionFunction has been manipulated and uses computeValue to evaluate the expression. As shown in Figure 8, the function variable now points directly to javax.lang.Runtime.exec, which is Java's standard method for running operating system commands. The parameters to be passed to this function include the attacker's command, and the highlighted line executes the command.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152663\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 8. Malicious code execution.[\/caption]\r\nExposed Vulnerable Servers\r\nCortex Xpanse telemetry data from March and April 2025 revealed 7,126 publicly exposed GeoServer instances across 99 countries. The five countries where these instances are hosted the most are shown in Figure 9. The majority of the exposed servers are hosted in China.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152674\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 9. Exposed GeoServer distribution in the five countries where they are most commonly hosted.[\/caption]\r\nAttack Chain Analysis\r\nWe have captured multiple distinct exploit strategies from this campaign. All strategies aim to deploy and run an SDK on the victim system. This analysis reviews an SDK variant we have designated as z593. Figure 10 shows that stage one leverages CVE-2024-36401 to download the second-stage payload z593 from a malicious host under the attacker\u2019s control.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152685\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 10. Stage 1: the initial exploit used to download the second-stage payload.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nDuring stage two, the attacker uses CVE-2024-36401 again to execute the second-stage payload z593, as shown in Figure 11.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152696\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 11. Stage 2: the exploit that executes the second-stage payload.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nInstead of using a standard HTTP web server, the attackers deployed private instances of a file-sharing server using transfer.sh to distribute their payloads. As shown in Figure 12, the instance of transfer.sh is hosted on one of the attacker\u2019s distribution IP addresses.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152707\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 12. Screenshot of the index page from a Transfer.sh server the attackers hosted on 64.226.112[.]52:8080.[\/caption]The deployments noted in Figure 12 were listening on port 8080 across two IP addresses under the attackers' control:\r\n\r\n \t64.226.112[.]52\r\n \t37.187.74[.]75\r\n\r\nIf the initial exploit is successful, the script then acts as a stager, fetching two additional files, as shown in Figure 13.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152718\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"635\"] Figure 13. Content of file z593 from 64.226.112[.]52 leading to additional files.[\/caption]&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThe first script named in Figure 13 is z401, which is designed for stealth, creating a hidden directory and placing the main executable within it as noted in Figure 14.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152729\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 14. Content of z401 from 64.226.112[.]52.[\/caption]&nbsp;\r\n\r\nFigure 15 shows how the second script from Figure 13, z402, establishes the environment and then launches the main executable, passing it the app key.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152740\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 15. Content of z402 from 64.226.112[.]52.[\/caption]Once running, the executable operates covertly in the background, monitoring device resources and illicitly sharing the victim's bandwidth whenever possible. This generates passive income for the attacker.\r\n\r\nThe executable files from these exploit attempts are designed to interact with two legitimate services: the misused app and the misused SDK. Both services legitimately offer users a way to generate passive income by sharing the network resources of idle devices.\r\n\r\nIn this context, attackers co-opt the app or SDK functionality. Similar to how cryptocurrency miners commandeer system resources for revenue, these exploited applications also use device resources for financial gain. However, unlike malicious cryptocurrency miners, this type of app or SDK misuse is typically with a lower profile. This attracts less attention and yields smaller profits for the threat actor, which can contribute to longer, undetected operations.\r\nMisused App Analysis\r\nFurther analysis of the binary that attackers installed on the victim\u2019s server reveals that the attackers have been using Dart as shown in Figure 16, Dart is an open-source programming language. Two key reasons likely motivated this choice:\r\n\r\n \tMonetization via SDK: The attackers used Dart to integrate the passive income SDK and interact with its service. This interaction is designed to ensure the generation and collection of passive income streams for the threat actor.\r\n \tCross-platform capability for Linux: The attackers also used Dart\u2019s inherent portability. They leveraged this feature to compile the executable specifically for Linux system architectures to expand their potential target environments.\r\n\r\nAdopting Dart for these purposes is noteworthy, as it may represent an attempt to potentially evade detection signatures primarily focused on languages more commonly associated with malware.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_152751\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"710\"] Figure 16. Binary using Dart for multi-platform capability.[\/caption]\r\nMisused SDK Analysis\r\nTo verify the nature of the SDK component used in this campaign, we compared the misused SDK binary employed by the threat attack and the official SDK version from the vendor\u2019s website. Our analysis confirmed that the two files are identical. This suggests the attackers are using a legitimate, unmodified SDK, which could bypass endpoint detection.\r\nConclusion\r\nThis ongoing campaign showcases a significant evolution in how adversaries monetize compromised systems. The attackers' core strategy focuses on stealthy, persistent monetization rather than aggressive resource exploitation. They achieve this by deploying executables that exploit legitimate passive income services, discreetly using device resources for activities like bandwidth sharing. This approach favors long-term, low-profile revenue generation over easily detectable techniques.\r\n\r\nTo combat this threat, we highly recommend applying patches and updates when possible.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected against vulnerabilities and malware through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention can block the attacks with best practices via Threat Prevention signatures 95463. In addition, ATP includes machine learning-based protection that can detect exploit traffic in real time.\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire can stop the customized executable from being transferred.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security are able to block known malicious URLs associated with this activity.\r\n \tCortex XDR\u00a0and XSIAM can block the exploitation of the vulnerabilities mentioned in this article.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 000 800 050 45107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nIP Addresses and TCP Ports Used for the Campaign Infrastructure\r\n\r\n \t37.187.74[.]75:8080\r\n \t64.226.112[.]52:8080\r\n\r\nCampaign Artifacts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hash of the File\r\nURL Contacted by the     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x

</script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    
<section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
			              <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/" role="link" title="Vulnerabilities" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:hero:breadcrumb:Vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</a></li> </ul>
            </div>            <div class="ab__title">
              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:hero:Vulnerabilities"><span class="ab-title__pre">Vulnerabilities</span></a> 
              <h1>Your Connection, Their Cash: Threat Actors Misuse SDKs to Sell Your Bandwidth</h1>
              <div class="ab__video">
              <span class="duration"> 
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-clock.svg" alt="Clock Icon"><span class="span-reading-time rt-reading-time"><span class="rt-label rt-prefix"></span> <span class="rt-time"> 10</span> <span class="rt-label rt-postfix"></span></span> min read              </span>
                              </div>          
              <div class="ab-lc__wrapper">
                <span class="ab-title__pre">Related Products</span><div class="ab__link-cards"><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" 				</li>
	  </ul>

            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-152574-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>We have detected a campaign aimed at gaining access to victims’ machines and monetizing access to their bandwidth. It functions by exploiting the <a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2024-36401" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CVE-2024-36401</a> vulnerability in the GeoServer geospatial database. This Critical-severity remote code execution vulnerability has a <a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CVSS score</a> of 9.8. Criminals have used the vulnerability to deploy legitimate software development kits (SDKs) or modified apps to gain passive income via network sharing or residential proxies.</p>
<p>This method of generating passive income is particularly stealthy. It mimics a monetization strategy used by some legitimate app developers who choose SDKs instead of displaying traditional ads. This can be a well-intentioned choice that protects the user experience and improves app retention.</p>
<p>The applications we found in this malicious activity are nearly silent when operating. They consume minimal resources while monetizing victims' internet bandwidth, and without creating or distributing malware. This integration allows app developers to receive payments, while criminals profit from unused server resources, minimizing their risk of detection.</p>
<p>Since March 2025, attackers have been probing GeoServer instances exposed to the internet. <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> reported 3,706 publicly accessible GeoServers in the first week of May 2025, indicating a potentially large attack surface for adversaries targeting CVE-2024-36401.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats described through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Vulnerabilities</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_vn2c6ues1fzs"></a>Campaign Dissection</h2>
<p>We have closely monitored a campaign that first emerged in early March 2025. The attackers have shifted infrastructure as well as tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) to maintain persistence.</p>
<p>We detected that attackers misused an SDK and an app during their campaign:</p>
<ul>
<li>The SDK allowed developers to monetize other apps by collecting user data to earn passive income.</li>
<li>The app allowed users to earn passive income by sharing their internet connection.</li>
</ul>
<p>The following timeline reveals how this threat has evolved.</p>
<h3><a id="post-152574-_5q3ft1ioc0n7"></a>Phase 1: Initial Incursion (Early March 2025) With Misused SDKs</h3>
<p>The campaign began with exploit attempts targeting CVE-2024-36401, then delivered the misused app and the misused SDK payloads.</p>
<ul>
<li>March 8, 2025: The campaign began with exploit attempts originating from the source IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">108.251.152[.]209</span>. The attacker used an exploit that targeted CVE-2024-36401.</li>
<li>Customized executable distribution: We observed these initial exploits fetching customized executables hosted at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">37.187.74[.]75</span>.</li>
<li>Two primary executables were distributed from this host:
<ul>
<li>The misused app: We detected variants of an application, including three that we have designated as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a193</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d193</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e193</span>.</li>
<li>The misused SDK: We detected variants of an SDK, including five that we have designated as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a593</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c593</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d593</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">s593</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z593</span>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-152574-_p2zca1mcn5ev"></a>Phase 2: Shifting Tactics (Late March - Early April 2025) With Misused SDKs</h3>
<p>Attackers shifted tactics during this phase of the campaign.</p>
<ul>
<li>March 24, 2025: A few vendors on VirusTotal flagged the distribution IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">37.187.74[.]75</span> as malicious. This shift indicates that the security community began recognizing malicious activity originating from that IP address. We believe this is a key factor that drove the threat actor to move their infrastructure to a different IP address.</li>
<li>March 26, 2025: The attackers appeared to stop distributing new misused app samples. The focus seemingly shifted entirely to the misused SDK.</li>
<li>April 1, 2025: The threat actors switched their primary exploit delivery infrastructure to a new source IP address, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.246.84[.]189</span>. This was likely an attempt to evade blocklists and continue their operations unhindered.</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-152574-_qmec1cdjp5ze"></a>Phase 3: Infrastructure Expansion and Persistence (Mid-April 2025 - Ongoing)</h3>
<p>Attackers expanded their infrastructure during this phase of the campaign.</p>
<ul>
<li>April 17, 2025: The attackers further expanded their backend infrastructure. They brought online a new customized executable distribution IP address, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52</span>.</li>
<li>The original distribution IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">37.187.74[.]75</span> remained live in mid-June.</li>
</ul>
<p>As of this writing, exploit attempts continue from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.246.84[.]189</span>, and the customized executable distribution hosts remain online.</p>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_69igxl4gtcyk"></a>CVE-2024-36401 Exploit Analysis</h2>
<p>The core of this vulnerability lies in an attacker's ability to inject arbitrary code into JXPath query statements. JXPath is a library within the Apache Commons project that offers an XPath implementation.</p>
<p>XPath is a widely adopted standard for querying and transforming XML documents. JXPath transparently extends the use of XPath expressions to various Java data structures beyond XML, including JavaBeans and multiple collections. From a security standpoint, this additional flexibility also introduces significant concerns.</p>
<p>JXPath supports <a href="https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-jxpath/apidocs/index.html#extension-functions-heading" target="_blank" rel="noopener">extension functionality</a>, which an attacker can exploit if they gain control over the query statement, allowing them to execute arbitrary code. This poses a greater risk than typical query injection vulnerabilities.</p>
<p>For instance, attackers have used Standard Extension Functions to invoke methods like <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>getRuntime().exec()</em></span>.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows an example of malicious code that leverages JXPath's ability to evaluate expressions, allowing an attacker to inject and execute arbitrary system commands via the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">#{cmd}</span> placeholder. By referencing <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">exec(java.lang.Runtime.getRuntime()</span> within <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">context.getValue</span>, an attacker triggers Java's runtime execution mechanism, leading to remote code execution on the target system.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152586" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152586" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152586 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-799984-152574-1.png" alt="A line of code displayed on a dark background features a command injection vulnerability using Java Runtime to execute an unwanted command." width="1000" height="134" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-799984-152574-1.png 1164w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-799984-152574-1-786x105.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-799984-152574-1-768x103.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152586" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Malicious code containing a JXPath referencing a Java execution function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 2 reveals the payload from this attack. We redacted the key part of the payload in Figure 2. The redacted portion forces the victim to execute a system command to download a file from the attacker's host distribution IP addresses.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152597" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152597" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152597 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-802646-152574-2.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer code snippet, including tags such as GetPropertyValue and ValueReference. The background is black with green text. Some of the information is redacted. " width="1000" height="245" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-802646-152574-2.png 1812w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-802646-152574-2-786x193.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-802646-152574-2-768x188.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-802646-152574-2-1536x376.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152597" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Payload from an exploit found in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p>According to the <a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2024-36401" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NVD</a>:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><em>This vulnerability has been confirmed to be exploitable through various Web Feature Service (WFS), Web Map Service (WMS), and Web Processing Service (WPS) requests, including GetFeature, GetPropertyValue, GetMap, GetFeatureInfo, GetLegendGraphic, and Execute requests.</em></p>
<p>While analyzing an exploit used in this attack, we set up a GeoServer instance and used an in-the-wild exploit payload to analyze how the exploit works. We can see what is happening inside GeoServer by following its code flow.</p>
<p>After we simulated sending an attack payload, our command was passed to the function <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>GetPropertyValue</em></span>. As shown at the bottom of Figure 3, the highlighted line takes the incoming <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>request</em></span> object and passes it to a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>run</em></span> method. The command is carried by<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em> request.valueReference</em></span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152608" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152608" style="width: 917px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152608 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-806367-152574-3.png" alt="Screenshot of code on an IDE, including a method definition within a class marked as overriding a method from an implemented service. The code includes syntax highlighting with red and blue colors." width="917" height="287" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-806367-152574-3.png 917w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-806367-152574-3-786x246.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-806367-152574-3-768x240.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 917px) 100vw, 917px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152608" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Malicious payload entry point.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Stepping into this function reveals that the payload from Figure 2 was passed to the object <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>propertyNameNoIndexes</em></span>, shown from the exploit code in Figure 4. Later, this object invokes the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Geotools</span> method <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>evaluate</em></span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152619" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152619" style="width: 985px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152619 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-809070-152574-4.png" alt="Screenshot of code in an IDE featuring syntax highlighting, displaying methods and exception handling related to attribute properties. The image shows multiple lines of code with comments and error indicators." width="985" height="264" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-809070-152574-4.png 985w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-809070-152574-4-786x211.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-809070-152574-4-768x206.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 985px) 100vw, 985px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152619" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. The malicious payload is sent to an unsafe <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Geotools</span> method.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Note that we have entered the <a href="https://geotools.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GeoTools</a> codebase. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">evaluate</span> method retrieves the value of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Geotools</span> attribute from the given object. Within this method, a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>PropertyAccessor</em></span> object is used to read the property. Figure 5 shows that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>PropertyAccessor</em></span> is a core interface that defines operations for reading and writing property values of an object. GeoTools will attempt to find an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>accessor</em></span> based on the provided parameters.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152630" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152630" style="width: 834px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152630 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-812517-152574-5.png" alt="Screenshot of code in an IDE program, featuring several methods and if-else statements, displayed with line numbers and syntax highlighting. The PropertyAccessors line is highlighted." width="834" height="353" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-812517-152574-5.png 834w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-812517-152574-5-786x333.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-812517-152574-5-768x325.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 834px) 100vw, 834px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152630" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. The malicious payload is sent to the object <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">PropertyAccessor</span> method <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">findPropertyAccessors</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>accessor</em></span> has been successfully found, it will use the object's get method to retrieve the property value. Figure 6 shows that our payload has been passed into that method via the parameter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>attPath</em></span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152641" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152641" style="width: 845px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152641 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-815481-152574-6.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen displaying code in an IDE, including functions and properties written in a programming language, with focus on a method named 'getAttributeExpression'." width="845" height="481" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-815481-152574-6.png 845w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-815481-152574-6-773x440.png 773w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-815481-152574-6-768x437.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 845px) 100vw, 845px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152641" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. A malicious payload is passed to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attPath</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The object's get method invokes the JXPath library function <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-jxpath/apidocs/org/apache/commons/jxpath/ri/JXPathContextReferenceImpl.html#iteratePointers(java.lang.String)" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>iteratePointers</em></a></span>. As shown in Figure 7, a payload is injected into the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>xpath</em></span> variable, which is then passed to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>context.iteratePointers</em></span> method.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152652" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152652" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152652 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-819180-152574-7.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code in an Integrated Development Environment, related to HTTP requests and error handling." width="1000" height="216" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-819180-152574-7.png 1414w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-819180-152574-7-786x170.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-819180-152574-7-768x166.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152652" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. JXPath function <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">iteratePointers</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>ExtensionFunction</em></span> has been manipulated and uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-jxpath/apidocs/org/apache/commons/jxpath/ri/JXPathContextReferenceImpl.html#iteratePointers(java.lang.String)" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>computeValue</em></a></span> to evaluate the expression. As shown in Figure 8, the function variable now points directly to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>javax.lang.Runtime.exec</em></span>, which is Java's standard method for running operating system commands. The parameters to be passed to this function include the attacker's command, and the highlighted line executes the command.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152663" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152663" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152663 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-822047-152574-8.png" alt="Screenshot of a coding interface in an IDE showing HTML and JavaScript code." width="1000" height="95" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-822047-152574-8.png 1593w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-822047-152574-8-786x75.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-822047-152574-8-768x73.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-822047-152574-8-1536x147.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152663" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Malicious code execution.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_gb9f60kcwzuy"></a>Exposed Vulnerable Servers</h2>
<p>Cortex Xpanse telemetry data from March and April 2025 revealed 7,126 publicly exposed GeoServer instances across 99 countries. The five countries where these instances are hosted the most are shown in Figure 9. The majority of the exposed servers are hosted in China.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152674" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152674" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152674 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7.png" alt="Bar chart showing the distribution of exposed GeoServers among the top five countries. China has the highest count, above 2,500, followed by the US, Germany, Great Britain, and Singapore with significantly lower counts." width="1000" height="619" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7-711x440.png 711w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7-1131x700.png 1131w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7-768x475.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/chart-7-1536x950.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152674" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Exposed GeoServer distribution in the five countries where they are most commonly hosted.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_dpdrm5iv6stj"></a>Attack Chain Analysis</h2>
<p>We have captured multiple distinct exploit strategies from this campaign. All strategies aim to deploy and run an SDK on the victim system. This analysis reviews an SDK variant we have designated as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z593</span>. Figure 10 shows that stage one leverages CVE-2024-36401 to download the second-stage payload <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z593</span> from a malicious host under the attacker’s control.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152685" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152685" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152685 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10.png" alt="Image displaying a code snippet in XML format, related to WFS and includes references to Java Runtime executables and system paths. The visual background of the coding area is dark, with text highlighted in green, red, yellow, and white." width="1000" height="218" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10-786x171.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10-1920x418.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10-768x167.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-830852-152574-10-1536x335.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152685" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Stage 1: the initial exploit used to download the second-stage payload.</figcaption></figure>
<p>During stage two, the attacker uses CVE-2024-36401 again to execute the second-stage payload <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z593</span>, as shown in Figure 11.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152696" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152696" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152696 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-833924-152574-11.png" alt="A screenshot displaying XML code related to a WFS with namespace URLs and a query using a Java runtime environment." width="1000" height="243" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-833924-152574-11.png 1678w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-833924-152574-11-786x191.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-833924-152574-11-768x187.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-833924-152574-11-1536x373.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152696" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Stage 2: the exploit that executes the second-stage payload.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Instead of using a standard HTTP web server, the attackers deployed private instances of a file-sharing server using <a href="https://github.com/dutchcoders/transfer.sh?tab=readme-ov-file#transfersh---" target="_blank" rel="noopener">transfer.sh</a> to distribute their payloads. As shown in Figure 12, the instance of transfer.sh is hosted on one of the attacker’s distribution IP addresses.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_152707" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152707" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152707 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-837712-152574-12.png" alt="Screenshot of a website titled &quot;Easy file sharing from the command line&quot; displaying examples of file upload commands and a drag-and-drop area for files, with a &quot;Learn more&quot; button at the bottom. An IP addtess is on the top left. " width="1000" height="496" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-837712-152574-12.png 1427w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-837712-152574-12-786x390.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-837712-152574-12-1411x700.png 1411w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-837712-152574-12-768x381.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152707" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Screenshot of the index page from a Transfer.sh server the attackers hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52:8080</span>.</figcaption></figure>The deployments noted in Figure 12 were listening on port 8080 across two IP addresses under the attackers' control:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">37.187.74[.]75</span></li>
</ul>
<p>If the initial exploit is successful, the script then acts as a stager, fetching two additional files, as shown in Figure 13.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152718" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152718" style="width: 635px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152718 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-840696-152574-13.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer terminal displaying commands to download files using wget from specific IP addresses." width="635" height="97" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152718" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Content of file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z593</span> from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52</span> leading to additional files.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The first script named in Figure 13 is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z401</span>, which is designed for stealth, creating a hidden directory and placing the main executable within it as noted in Figure 14.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152729" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152729" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152729 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-843972-152574-14.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer terminal displaying Unix shell commands for removing, creating, and navigating directories, along with a command to download a file using wget from a specified IP address." width="1000" height="331" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-843972-152574-14.png 1118w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-843972-152574-14-786x260.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-843972-152574-14-768x254.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152729" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Content of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z401</span> from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 15 shows how the second script from Figure 13, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z402</span>, establishes the environment and then launches the main executable, passing it the app key.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_152740" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152740" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152740 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-847831-152574-15.png" alt="Text displayed in a terminal window showing a command line interface with code involved in configuring an environment variable named 'PATH'." width="1000" height="111" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-847831-152574-15.png 1824w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-847831-152574-15-786x87.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-847831-152574-15-768x85.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-847831-152574-15-1536x170.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152740" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Content of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z402</span> from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.226.112[.]52</span>.</figcaption></figure>Once running, the executable operates covertly in the background, monitoring device resources and illicitly sharing the victim's bandwidth whenever possible. This generates passive income for the attacker.</p>
<p>The executable files from these exploit attempts are designed to interact with two legitimate services: the misused app and the misused SDK. Both services legitimately offer users a way to generate passive income by sharing the network resources of idle devices.</p>
<p>In this context, attackers co-opt the app or SDK functionality. Similar to how cryptocurrency miners commandeer system resources for revenue, these exploited applications also use device resources for financial gain. However, unlike malicious cryptocurrency miners, this type of app or SDK misuse is typically with a lower profile. This attracts less attention and yields smaller profits for the threat actor, which can contribute to longer, undetected operations.</p>
<h3><a id="post-152574-_j4kx31g0xkwd"></a>Misused App Analysis</h3>
<p>Further analysis of the binary that attackers installed on the victim’s server reveals that the attackers have been using <a href="https://github.com/dart-lang" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dart</a> as shown in Figure 16, Dart is an open-source programming language. Two key reasons likely motivated this choice:</p>
<ul>
<li>Monetization via SDK: The attackers used Dart to integrate the passive income SDK and interact with its service. This interaction is designed to ensure the generation and collection of passive income streams for the threat actor.</li>
<li>Cross-platform capability for Linux: The attackers also used Dart’s inherent portability. They leveraged this feature to compile the executable specifically for Linux system architectures to expand their potential target environments.</li>
</ul>
<p>Adopting Dart for these purposes is noteworthy, as it may represent an attempt to potentially evade detection signatures primarily focused on languages more commonly associated with malware.</p>
<figure id="attachment_152751" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-152751" style="width: 710px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-152751 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-850821-152574-16.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer programming interface displaying a list of code and functions primarily associated with the Dart programming language. It highlights a specific string. " width="710" height="400" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-152751" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Binary using Dart for multi-platform capability.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-152574-_a0ntqazecu39"></a>Misused SDK Analysis</h3>
<p>To verify the nature of the SDK component used in this campaign, we compared the misused SDK binary employed by the threat attack and the official SDK version from the vendor’s website. Our analysis confirmed that the two files are identical. This suggests the attackers are using a legitimate, unmodified SDK, which could bypass endpoint detection.</p>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This ongoing campaign showcases a significant evolution in how adversaries monetize compromised systems. The attackers' core strategy focuses on stealthy, persistent monetization rather than aggressive resource exploitation. They achieve this by deploying executables that exploit legitimate passive income services, discreetly using device resources for activities like bandwidth sharing. This approach favors long-term, low-profile revenue generation over easily detectable techniques.</p>
<p>To combat this threat, we highly recommend applying patches and updates when possible.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected against vulnerabilities and malware through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> can block the attacks with best practices via Threat Prevention signatures 95463. In addition, ATP includes machine learning-based protection that can detect exploit traffic in real time.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> can stop the customized executable from being transferred.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> are able to block known malicious URLs associated with this activity.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can block the exploitation of the vulnerabilities mentioned in this article.</span></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 000 800 050 45107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-152574-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>

<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">33aad585d6280d1921b5f46f8894ee05d426c7751c2133ed5484bf65af587576</span></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7620f22a5ed1a8ac2a1da732e55e14a13197b631e5abba6431f88e5cfa3ae2de</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://64.226.112[.]52:8080/rKS64mUmF7/d593</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3d7ac752bb0d54802f2def38f44e10854f70ab5a9a001b5c39ab0531b9ed74bf</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://64.226.112[.]52:8080/vbbdG8dpAw/s401</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ae706c149497c2fc809682e8827996ea3ceb7bcecddd87be7543d1dca4853470</span></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6dd6751bae92dfa504f0ad5558ab8adfdfba3df5a7f218245627574bfac39f11</span></td>

<h2><a id="post-152574-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>

				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cl-cri-1040/" title="CL-CRI-1040" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:Active Exploitation of Microsoft SharePoint Vulnerabilities: Threat Brief (Updated August 12):CL-CRI-1040">CL-CRI-1040</a>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of infiltration of global telecom networks.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-29T21:00:16+00:00">July 29, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/infiltration-of-global-telecom-networks/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks">
                    <h4 class="post-title">The Covert Operator's Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/advanced-persistent-threat/" title="Advanced Persistent Threat" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:Advanced Persistent Threat">Advanced Persistent Threat</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" title="backdoor" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:backdoor">Backdoor</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cl-sta-0969/" title="CL-STA-0969" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:CL-STA-0969">CL-STA-0969</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/infiltration-of-global-telecom-networks/" title="The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of CVEs such as CVE-2025-24813, CVE-2025-27636, CVE-2025-29891. Digital illustration of the United States with glowing connections and data flows across a map, symbolizing network connectivity and information technology." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/06_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:Apache Under the Lens: Tomcat’s Partial PUT and Camel’s Header Hijack:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-03T10:00:03+00:00">July 3, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/apache-cve-2025-24813-cve-2025-27636-cve-2025-29891/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="attackers-sell-your-bandwidth-using-sdks:related-resources:Apache Under the Lens: Tomcat’s Partial PUT and Camel’s Header Hijack">
